content.description: Classic to the right of "Cerro K'Narlé" and the diagonaling "Orange Chimney" (5.9) route.
content.location: Just to the right of the Orange Chimney on the south face of The Sphinx formation.

climbs.name: Single Pitch Bolt and Pro Route

content.description: A single pitch line with a few bolts and natural pieces of protection.
content.protection: Regular rack plus quick draws for the bolts. Double bolt anchor at the belay.
content.location: On the face just to the left of "The Great Googley Boogley".

content.description: Climb the obvious orange chimney on the right (west) end of the south face of The Sphinx. Said to be "crumbly".
content.protection: Regular rack, but since this is a little known route bring along some extra big gear for sure.
content.location: Far left edge of The Sphinx formation.

climbs.name: Northeast Ridge
climbs.fa: W.G. Yongue (Gerald Yongue) August 19, 1938. Entire East Ridge was done in 1959 and repeated in 1977 by Kennec, Rupert, & Pearson.

content.description:
The East Ridge can be climbed from the saddle, which is easily accessed from the backside. But the entire East Ridge can be traversed, starting from the unofficial campground at the curve on US 120 along Warren Creek. This second way is a bit loose, but still only 5.7.

It is also possible to continue on past the summit of the Sphinx and down into the saddle on the backside of the formation, and then on up the orange rock ridge to the West - Northwest. Ian Ferguson has done this to the high point of that ridge.
content.location: Along the East Ridge of the Sphinx. Approach from the Warren Creek trail head.

content.description:
Pitch 1 starts in an alcove with plenty of friable rock (watch your head). Do a series of moves up to a traversing roof then under it with just enough feet to keep it sane. Pitch 2 goes up and around some stacked blocks, then on to a traversing horizontal crack, with no feet really, but once again just enough to get you by the exposed piece, then more jamming up steep corners to the next belay ledge, which isn't much more than the top of a block just big enough for your feet. Pitch 3 starts out steep again, finds a roof, traverses out and left, with just enough footholds to make it possible. Getting  past a large loose block to the belay is a tremendous relief. The 4th pitch (5.7) is low angle and takes you up to the summit. Sort of a let down considering the first three pitches had absolutely wonderful 5.10 moves.

Note: Some loose rock. Good climbing.
content.protection: Pro to 4". Doubles to 3". Many long slings. The descent is 4th class with some rappells to make it go faster.
content.location: Up the center of the Sphinx formation which is a little more than a half mile east down the Tioga Road from the Rhinedollar Dam on Ellery Lake. Look up. You can't miss it.

content.description: Climbs the south-east face of The Sphinx formation through some nice corners cracks and overhangs. "Nice Sierra granite", says Sibylle Hechtel in an old summit registry entry. The route starts with a 3rd class scramble up and right to the base of the Orange Chimney where the real climbing begins. P1 Cross over Orange Chimney, climb 5.10a face, and climb up under arch. P2 45' classic fist crack to horizontal break. P3 Climb face to upper corner. P4 The last pitch goes through a roof at 5.9 and finishes on the Sphinx summit.
content.location: Starts left of the Orange Chimney (5.9) and crosses it to access a series of gorgeous hand cracks that will take you to the summit of The Sphinx.

content.description: Climbs cracks and corners to the right of Great Googley Boogley, finishing with a crack splitting the upper headwall.
content.location: South face of The Sphinx formation just right of Great Googley Boogley.
